Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A casual conversation drifts toward personal topics but nothing particularly sensitive is mentioned.
Story:
As a grandfather, I always look forward to the family holiday. It’s the one time of year when everyone gathers, and I’m expected to keep the family close, sharing stories and checking in on everyone’s lives. This year, as we sat around the living room, my daughter asked about my volunteer work at the community center. She wanted to know about the people I help, curious if I’d met anyone interesting. I could feel the family’s eyes on me, expecting a story, a connection, something to bring us closer.

But as a volunteer, I know I’m trusted to respect the privacy of those I help. Even though nothing sensitive had come up in my conversations at the center, I felt a knot in my stomach. The family wanted warmth and openness, but I was bound by a promise of confidentiality, even in the smallest details. I could sense their disappointment as I hesitated, torn between sharing to strengthen our family bond and keeping my word to those who had trusted me. The room grew quiet, and I wrestled with what to say next.
